body:
Thanks for your pull request.  It looks like this may be your first contribution to a Google open source project. Before we can look at your pull request, you'll need to sign a Contributor License Agreement (CLA).

:memo: **Please visit https://cla.developers.google.com/ to sign.**

Once you've signed, please reply here (e.g. `I signed it!`) and we'll verify.  Thanks.

---
- If you've already signed a CLA, it's possible we don't have your GitHub username or you're using a different email address.  Check [your existing CLA data](https://cla.developers.google.com/clas) and verify that your [email is set on your git commits](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
- If you signed the CLA as a corporation, please let us know the company's name.

<!-- need_sender_cla -->

@murgatroid99 @cv - What is missing to get this merged in? This seems extremely simple.

Sorry, this kind of dropped off my radar. Are you sure that this change doesn't break anything? In particular, if the included file is in a sibling directory relative to the including file, a simple `require_relative` may do the wrong thing.

> Are you sure that this change doesn't break anything? In particular, if the included file is in a sibling directory relative to the including file, a simple require_relative may do the wrong thing.

Based on my understanding from this thread and the ruby docs, it should be ok: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3672586/what-is-the-difference-between-require-relative-and-require-in-ruby

The current implementation could falter as well if the `$LOAD_PATH` contains a file named `user.rb` for example and there's a protofile also called `user.rb`.

I know what `require_relative` does. My point is that currently, if you have on your load path `lib/messages.rb` and `test/services.rb`, then if `test/services.rb` has the line `require "lib/messages.rb"`, that works, but if you change it to `require_relative`, it won't work.

I'm confused, require relative will use the path of the file that it is contained in. Not the file including it. All this change does it ensure that that all generated files from grpc play nicely when you drop them into a project. I'm fairly certain this change won't break current implementations.

That's not what I'm talking about. I'm saying that `dep.name` does not necessarily correspond to the path of the dependency relative to the current file. Rather, it can correspond to the path of the dependency relative to some other point in the file system.
What is the scenario for that so I can try it out?
I described a scenario two messages ago. Have two files in different directories, with one loading the other using `require`. Change that `require` to `require_relative`, and see if it still works.
